Taura Syndrome (TS)

Symptoms:

  • Reddish coloration on the body and tail
  • Reddish coloration on the body and tail
  • Reddish coloration on the body and tail
  • Reddish coloration on the body and tail
  • Reddish coloration on the body and tail
  • Reddish coloration on the body and tail

Description

aura Syndrome (TS) is a highly infectious viral disease caused by the *Taura Syndrome Virus* (TSV), primarily affecting *Penaeus vannamei* shrimp. It is most dangerous in post-larval and juvenile shrimp, leading to significant mortality in commercial shrimp farms. The disease progresses in three stages: an acute phase, a transitional phase, and a chronic phase. In the acute phase, affected shrimp show reddish discoloration, particularly on the tail, and experience mass die-offs. The transitional phase involves slow recovery but with visible black gill spots. In the chronic phase, surviving shrimp may continue to carry the virus asymptomatically. TSV spreads through infected shrimp, contaminated water, and poor biosecurity. Environmental stress, such as sudden changes in water temperature or pollution, can worsen outbreaks.

Treatment

There is no specific antiviral treatment for Taura Syndrome. Management focuses on biosecurity measures like disinfecting water, controlling stocking density, and ensuring proper nutrition. Farmers should remove infected shrimp immediately and improve water quality to reduce stress. Some resistant shrimp strains have been developed for farming. Using probiotics and immune-boosting feeds can help prevent outbreaks.

Tips & Suggestions:

  • Use biosecure hatcheries for virus-free stock
  • Use biosecure hatcheries for virus-free stock
  • Use biosecure hatcheries for virus-free stock
  • Use biosecure hatcheries for virus-free stock
  • Use biosecure hatcheries for virus-free stock
  • Use biosecure hatcheries for virus-free stock
